item.title: Multiple Instances of Skype
item.description:
Follow these steps to run multiple instances of Skype on same machine.

Windows</h3>
  • From the Windows taskbar, click Start</strong> > Run</strong> (or press the Windows </strong><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-293" src="http://blog.incognitech.in/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/fa829.png" alt="fa829" width="16" height="16" /></a> + R</strong> keys on your keyboard at the same time).</li>
  • In the Run window, type the following command (including the quotes) and press Ok</strong>:
    • For 32-bit operating systems: 
      "C:\Program Files\Skype\Phone\Skype.exe" /secondary</pre>
      
</li>

    • For 64-bit operating systems:

      "C:\Program Files (x86)\Skype\Phone\Skype.exe" /secondary</pre>
      
</li>
      
</ul>
      
</li>
      
</ul>

      Linux</h3>

        

      • Press Alt + F2</strong> and type the following command:

        skype --secondary</pre>
        
</li>

      • Alternative : </strong>Open a terminal and use the following command in it:

        skype --secondary &</pre>
        
</li>
        
</ul>

        Mac</h3>

          

        • Use this command in terminal:

          sudo /Applications/Skype.app/Contents/MacOS/Skype /secondary</code></pre>
          
</li>
          
</ul>

item.title: Temporary DB tables in WordPress PhpUnit
item.description:
When we set up WordPress-PhpUnit Environment</a>, to automate test-cases for our plugin/theme (mainly plugins, I've not come across any WP theme which has test cases written for it), we either set it up manually</a> or we take help of WP-CLI</a> to build the scaffolding of our plugin. WordPress has an amazing testcase wrapper class</a> for PhpUnit that can be used when we make out plugin testable.

Of course, when our plugin does not deal with database then we do not have to worry about as our plugin will only make use of the readily available tables of WordPress and there will not be any need to introduce new database tables. But if we deal with database tables through our plugin then we need these tables when we perform test-cases using PhpUnit. wpdb</a> & dbDelta</a> gives you enough power to play with database tables in your plugin. But when we are in PhpUnit environment, schematics are a bit different. WordPress testcase wrapper creates temporary DB tables in WordPress PhpUnit environment. What this means is when we execute test-cases for our plugin, the built-in wrapper class - mentioned before - tells WordPress to create temporary (virtual) tables in MySql and NOT permanent (actual) tables (Reference</a>). Because of this, your test-cases related DB tables will only exist during the PhpUnit execution. They will be destroyed from the memory.

The sole purpose of such mechanism is to keep the test data away from the database and not bloat the memory with corrupt data, keeping the database intact. If this is the case then you're good to go; but there are times when we can't move ahead and believe that everything is working absolutely fine until we see the actual results ;). We might need those database table to retain its state even after the PhpUnit execution. In that case we can use following solution:

Override setUp</code> method of WP_UnitTestCase</code> class in your own testcase class. The method definition should look as follows: 

function setUp() {

    // Perform the actual task according to parent class.

    parent::setUp();

    // Remove filters that will create temporary tables. So that permanent tables will be created.

    remove_filter( 'query', array( $this, '_create_temporary_table' ) );

    remove_filter( 'query', array( $this, '_drop_temporary_table' ) );

}

</pre>

Above code will do the trick. Happy coding & testing ! :)

item.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
item.description:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve --watch, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll’s dedicated Help repository.

item.title: Skype Notification Sound Distorted in Ubuntu
item.description:
It has been noticed and seems to be a common problem in Linux Community users that Skype doesn't get along well with Linux Distros. Recently I upgraded to Ubuntu 14.04 & I was sure enough that it's not going to be in peace for long. The very first problem I observed that the Skype notification sound distorted in Ubuntu when it played & also the distortion continued unless I logged out or shut down the machine.

Here are simple steps to follow in order to fix this issue:

  1. Open the file /etc/pulse/default.pa</code> in your favorite text editor with root privileges. E.g., sudo vim /etc/pulse/default.pa</code></li>
  2. Search for the line : load-module module-hal-detect</code></li>
  3. Append tsched=0</code> to the end. i.e., load-module module-hal-detect tsched=0</code></li>
  4. Restart pulse or just restart your machine & the distortion should be gone.</li>
  5. If you do not have a line with load-module module-hal-detect</code> then search for the line : load-module module-udev-detect</code></li>
  6. Append tsched=0</code> to the end. i.e., load-module module-udev-detect tsched=0</code>. And then restart the machine.</li>
    </ol>
    NOTE : Not sure what the side effects are by disabling Glitch Free Audio; but hey, at least it doesn't bug you with its annoying sound anymore :wink: :smile:

item.title: Probably Kavish's first #selfie wid Mamu jaans
